comments.body:
```suggestion
    - scipy 1.5
```
Are you really pinned exactly to scipy 1.5?
The challenge is that there are a few migrations underway, and 1.5 might make your environment unsolvable seeing as the latest package on conda-forge is 1.6.

As I understand it, `~=1.5.0` means a release [*compatible with*](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/#compatible-release) `1.5.0` which gets translated to `>=1.5.0,<1.6`

I believe `conda` translates `1.5` as `1.5.*` which is also equivalent to `>=1.5.0,<1.6` - so I think they're the same?

I tend to use the compatible release version as I think it's less ambiguous. i.e. I think it would be perfectly reasonable to expect `1.5` to be translated to `1.5.0` and a user just has to know that it actually means `1.5.*`. With the compatible release version the approximately equal to `~=` sign gives the reader a clue that it's not the same as exact equality.
If that's wrong our you'd still like the change I'm happy to commit it?
You can choose the notation you like. Are you sure you don't want scipy 1.6 as well?

It's what is specified upstream:
https://github.com/google-research/torchsde/blob/709968cc008f4bbfd6c63775974ac960b3746d4f/setup.py#L38

I tend to be conservative with going against upstream, particularly for compiled projects. That said, a lot of upstreams don't pin correctly (because it has never been an issue with `pip`).
Happy to loosen that to `>=1.5.0,<1.7` if you think it will cause issues as is though?

It seems there was a reason for the pinning:
[`5ef5ebc` (#86)](https://github.com/google-research/torchsde/pull/86/commits/5ef5ebca23fe20eab90094ffca186e371472e66f)

...though it's not clear what that was. Given that, I might be inclined to leave as is for now and open an issue upstream to relax the pinning. If that gets merged then I can put out a new build with the relaxed constraints. Sound reasonable?
yeah, i figured that was your line of thought.

yeah, i figured that was your line of thought.
